name: Arnab Nandy
title: Senior Associate - Projects · Cognizant
about: Full Stack Java Developer with over 10 years of experience across enterprise application development, API design, cloud platforms, and DevOps practices. Currently working as Senior Associate at Cognizant, leading cross-functional teams to deliver scalable and high-performance solutions. Passionate about problem-solving, automation, competitive programming, and sharing knowledge on StackOverflow.

work.summary: Leading cross-functional teams to deliver quality feature releases, architecting solutions, developing APIs and microservices, and optimizing performance. Tools & Tech: Java 8, Spring Boot, Postgres, Amazon S3, Apigee Gateway, Rally, Jenkins, Git, JMeter, Postman, Confluence.

Developed enterprise-grade Java/Spring applications and APIs, customized solutions per client requirements, and ensured performance with JMeter. Tech stack: Java8, Spring, Hibernate5, JPA, Swagger2, Postgres.

Worked on KoPT POMS project for port operations (cargo, billing, MIS). Responsibilities included design, development, and client interaction. Tech stack: Java, Spring, Hibernate, AngularJS, Oracle DB, Bootstrap, HTML5, CSS3.
Enhanced Delhi Jal Board RMS project for consumer services, billing, grievance handling, and SSO integration. Tech stack: Java, JSP-Servlet, Struts2, Oracle PL/SQL, Oracle CC&B, SVN.
Completed Job Enabled Training Program in System Integration (Java).
Initial hands-on training in Java and web development.

so_answers.question_title: How can I delete a user in Linux when the system says it's currently used in a process?
so_answers.excerpt: To delete a user when it's in use, first kill the active processes using `pkill -u username`, then remove the user with `userdel -r username`.

so_answers.question_title: How to pause/resume a process in Linux?
so_answers.excerpt: Use `kill -STOP <pid>` to pause a process and `kill -CONT <pid>` to resume it. These signals allow you to control jobs without killing them.
`pkill -f` matches against the full command line. If it's not working, make sure the string uniquely identifies the process or use `ps aux | grep` to verify.
